text: Family Member: I was always taught it’s an overgrowth of whatever. Doctor: Yeah. The cancer cells- Family Member: The cells just keep reproducing, reproducing, reproducing. Doctor: That’s it. It doesn’t know when to stop growing, which is the problem. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So it’s, you know, affected your bones. It’s affected some of the lymph nodes. So is it going like crazy gangbusters? No. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: I ain’t seen it in my lymph nodes. I check my lymph nodes. I ain’t seen none in my lymph nodes. Doctor: Well, you can’t see it. It’s inside when I do scans. So the good part is you don’t hurt or feel bad. Thank goodness. Family Member: Right. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So that’s great. But it doesn’t mean that we don’t do stuff because that’s why I check scans because it’s inside. So that’s, that’s why. Family Member: Um. Okay.

text: Family Member: That’s okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So um I think we should take it one step at a time and keep all our options open. So uh stay with the Xtandi and the Lupron and bring in the BET. And uh I I’m gonna be getting it from Midtown rather from here and they’ll know that? Doctor: Oh well once – what I was going to propose is that I give you the copy of the consent. If you want you can read it and uh if you’re ready to sign today you can, or we can schedule all the testing in anticipation of putting you on the study and all of that downtown and then that same day you can come in and sign the consent and do all the testing necessary. That gives you some time to think it over talk it over before signing. Patient: And you said it would just be a couple days I’d have to be there? Doctor: The two days are the long days. There are other days that you would be coming in and I just… Patient: For how long? Doctor: Well that’s what the consent will give you the exact details Patient: Okay, Yeah. Doctor: of how many times a week, but the first few weeks typically are very, what this is called is a Phase I study. So it’s an earlier setting like I said the combination really we don’t have a good handle on what to expect in terms of toxicities, what dose, etc. So one of the side effects that has been noted so far is that the platelets can drop with this medication. So that is something of course the blood counts will be monitored anyway. Besides that kidney function, liver function, all that will also be monitored and checked. You go – undergo EKG monitoring that will be hard test like and echo before you start. So there is a lot of components. One additional component is that you probably will need to do a biopsy again as part of the study. Doctor: So that’s something to think about before you say yes or no. Patient: And does platelets dropping how would that affect me physically? Doctor: Well if it gets really low then it can cause bleeding and things like that -

text: Family Member: But then that means they won’t prick you every time for the blood draw. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So I stay all day downtown or midtown? Family Member: And why are they, why do they, that’s interesting. Doctor: Well because they want to see how the levels of the drug, how long it takes for it to clear and things like that. So frankly along with the Xtandi there are not – this is sort of the first study of combining it with either Xtandi or Zytega and you know the single agent studies they kind of have they know what to expect. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: But in combination they need to see how the drug levels behave. Patient: How many days will I have to be there? Doctor: I think there are two long days, but you’ll have the full schedule of how often you have to come in. Family Member: So this is a different clinical trial. Is it a clinical trial? Doctor: Different than the one he’s on. Yes. Family Member: Yeah so we’d be on two clinical trials?

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: and you may opt out. For example, if you had say I just want to focus on treating that area let’s just do it Patient: Okay. Doctor: now one of the things that about the trial is that it’s randomized. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: What does a randomized trial mean and in this particular case what are people are being randomized too. Randomized means that a computer and then essentially flips a coin and is random, very random in group A and group B of the clinical trial. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So in this study there is a random allocation of the therapy and random also means that neither the physician which is me nor the patient which is you knows So it truly is random. And also the computer program flips the coin so to speak, you can only flip it once, you can’t continue to flip over and over until you get the condition you want Patient: Okay. Doctor: So option one is what we call observation. Your option two is the stereotactic radiotherapy, which I mentioned is called SBRT for short. that in order to make this trial a little more attractive to patients is designed ins such a way that the odds of getting the radiotherapy are twice as high as the odds of getting the observation. So in other words, you can think of it as a three-headed coin, there’s a one out of three chance that you’re gonna get the observation group. That’s about a thirty-three percent chance. And there’s a two out of three chance or sixty-six percent that you will get the stereotactic radiotherapy which most people on this trial want to get. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Now if you get selected to go on the observation which is a one and three chance of that happening, the study was designed in such a way so that all patients eventually get the stereotactic radiotherapy because if you had a trial designed that way then people would not sign up for it.

Your option two is the stereotactic radiotherapy, which I mentioned is called SBRT for short. that in order to make this trial a little more attractive to patients is designed ins such a way that the odds of getting the radiotherapy are twice as high as the odds of getting the observation. So in other words, you can think of it as a three-headed coin, there’s a one out of three chance that you’re gonna get the observation group. That’s about a thirty-three percent chance. And there’s a two out of three chance or sixty-six percent that you will get the stereotactic radiotherapy which most people on this trial want to get. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Now if you get selected to go on the observation which is a one and three chance of that happening, the study was designed in such a way so that all patients eventually get the stereotactic radiotherapy because if you had a trial designed that way then people would not sign up for it.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
